<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}

Explanation:
You're creating a new `dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator()` in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the `Iterator.next()` inside the loop.

Regarding your second question, you can use the `get()` method of the `LinkedHashMap` to get the value by key. Here's an example of how you can use the `testMap` instead of hardcoding:

double percent = r.nextDouble()*100;
if(percent > 1.0 && percent < 70.0){
commands.get(commandWithMaxNegativeOffset).setDataCriteria(testMap.get(70.0));
} else if(percent > 71 && percent < 100){
commands.get(commandWithMaxNegativeOffset).setDataCriteria(testMap.get(30.0));
}

Explanation:
You can use the `get()` method of the `LinkedHashMap` to get the value by key. In the if/else loop, you can use the key/value pair from the `testMap` to set the `dataCriteria` of the `commands` object.
